docs.title: ⚡ Caching System
docs.text: EmojiTools uses intelligent caching to deliver lightning-fast search results. Understand how it works and how to manage it.

docs.title: How Caching Works
docs.text:
The caching system automatically stores search results and frequently accessed data to speed up subsequent operations:

  • First Search - Builds cache (may take a moment)
  • Subsequent Searches - Uses cache (10-100x faster!)
  • Auto-Refresh - Cache updates when dataset changes

docs.title: Clear Cache
docs.text:
# Clear all cached data
Clear-EmojiCache

# Cache rebuilds automatically on next search
Search-Emoji "rocket"

docs.title: Check Cache Status
docs.text:
# View cache information
Get-EmojiCacheStatus

Shows: - Cache size - Last updated - Hit/miss ratio - Cached items count

docs.title: Performance Impact
docs.text:
Without Cache: 

# First search (builds cache)
Measure-Command { Search-Emoji "heart" }
# ~200-500ms

With Cache: 

# Subsequent search (uses cache)
Measure-Command { Search-Emoji "heart" }
# ~10-50ms (10x faster!)

docs.text: Cache automatically clears when: - Dataset is updated - Custom dataset is loaded - Module is reimported

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Starting with EmojiTools 1.17.0, user data is stored in a version-independent location to preserve your custom data (history, collections, aliases, statistics) across module upgrades.

docs.title: Problem with Previous Versions
docs.text:
In versions prior to 1.17.0, data was stored inside the module directory:

C:\Users\username\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\EmojiTools\1.16.0\data\

When you upgraded to a new version (e.g., 1.17.0), PowerShell would install it alongside:

C:\Users\username\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\EmojiTools\1.17.0\data\

This caused: - ❌ Loss of emoji usage history - ❌ Loss of custom collections - ❌ Loss of custom aliases - ❌ Loss of usage statistics - ❌ Need to re-download emoji dataset

docs.title: New Data Location
docs.text:
Your data is now stored in a version-independent location:

Windows: 

C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\EmojiTools\

macOS/Linux: 

/home/username/.emojitools/

docs.title: Automatic Migration
docs.text:
When you first load EmojiTools 1.17.0+:

  1. ✅ Automatic detection: Module checks if migration is needed
  2. ✅ Safe migration: Copies data from old location to new location
  3. ✅ Non-destructive: Original files remain untouched
  4. ✅ One-time only: Migration only runs once per data directory

docs.title: What Gets Migrated
docs.text:
The following files are automatically migrated:

File Description history.json Your emoji usage history collections.json Your custom emoji collections aliases.json Your custom emoji aliases stats.json Your usage statistics emoji.csv Cached emoji dataset metadata.json Dataset metadata languages/* Installed language packs

docs.title: Manual Migration
docs.text: If you need to manually migrate data or use a custom location:

docs.title: Option 1: Use Environment Variable
docs.text:
Set a custom data path before importing the module:

$env:EMOJITOOLS_DATA_PATH = "D:\MyData\EmojiTools"
Import-Module EmojiTools

docs.title: Option 2: Manual Migration Function
docs.text:
Migrate data from a specific location:

# Import module first
Import-Module EmojiTools

# Migrate from old location
$oldPath = "C:\Users\username\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\EmojiTools\1.16.0\data"
$newPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath

Invoke-EmojiDataMigration -SourcePath $oldPath -DestinationPath $newPath -Force

docs.title: Option 3: Copy Files Manually
docs.text:
Copy these files from old location to new location:

# Get the new data path
$dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Write-Host "Copy files to: $dataPath"

# Old location (adjust version number)
$oldPath = "$HOME\Documents\PowerShell\Modules\EmojiTools\1.16.0\data"

# Copy files
Copy-Item "$oldPath\history.json" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\collections.json" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\aliases.json" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\stats.json" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\emoji.csv" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\metadata.json" -Destination $dataPath -Force
Copy-Item "$oldPath\languages" -Destination $dataPath -Recurse -Force

docs.title: Checking Your Data Location
docs.text:
View your current data directory:

Get-EmojiToolsDataPath

View detailed module information including data path:

Get-EmojiToolsInfo

docs.title: 1. Upgrade Safety
docs.text: Your data persists across module upgrades. No need to manually backup and restore.

docs.title: 2. Multiple Versions
docs.text: You can have multiple module versions installed without conflicts: - 1.15.0 (old format) - 1.16.0 (old format) - 1.17.0 (new format) ← Uses shared data directory - 1.18.0 (future) ← Uses same shared data directory

docs.title: 3. Easy Backup
docs.text:
Backup a single directory instead of searching through module versions:

$dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Copy-Item $dataPath -Destination "D:\Backups\EmojiTools-$(Get-Date -Format 'yyyy-MM-dd')" -Recurse

docs.title: 4. Portable Configuration
docs.text:
Export your data directory to move between machines:

# Machine 1: Export
$dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Compress-Archive -Path $dataPath -DestinationPath "EmojiTools-data.zip"

# Machine 2: Import
$dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Expand-Archive -Path "EmojiTools-data.zip" -DestinationPath $dataPath -Force

docs.title: Data Not Migrating
docs.text:
Symptom: Upgraded module but old data not available

Solutions:

  1. Check if migration completed: 

    $dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Test-Path (Join-Path $dataPath ".migrated")

  2. Manually trigger migration: 

    Initialize-EmojiToolsDataDirectory -Force

  3. Check old location still exists: 

    Get-Module EmojiTools -ListAvailable | Select-Object Version, ModuleBase
# Look for 1.15.0 folder and check if data\ exists

docs.title: Finding Old Data Location
docs.text:
List all installed EmojiTools versions:

Get-Module EmojiTools -ListAvailable | ForEach-Object {
    $dataPath = Join-Path $_.ModuleBase "data"
    [PSCustomObject]@{
        Version = $_.Version
        DataPath = $dataPath
        Exists = Test-Path $dataPath
        Files = if (Test-Path $dataPath) {
            (Get-ChildItem $dataPath -File).Name -join ", "
        } else {
            "N/A"
        }
    }
} | Format-Table -AutoSize

docs.title: Migration Errors
docs.text:
If migration fails, check:

  1. Permissions: Ensure you have write access to destination 

    $dataPath = Get-EmojiToolsDataPath
Test-Path $dataPath -IsValid
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path $dataPath -Force # Try creating

  2. Disk space: Ensure enough space (data is typically < 5 MB) 

    Get-PSDrive C | Select-Object Free

  3. File locks: Ensure no other process has files open 

    # Close all PowerShell sessions using EmojiTools
Get-Process powershell, pwsh | Where-Object {
    $_.Modules.ModuleName -contains "EmojiTools"
}

docs.title: Reverting to Old Location (Not Recommended)
docs.text:
If you need to use the module-embedded data location:

# Set environment variable to module path
$module = Get-Module EmojiTools
$env:EMOJITOOLS_DATA_PATH = Join-Path $module.ModuleBase "data"

# Reload module
Remove-Module EmojiTools -Force
Import-Module EmojiTools

⚠️ Warning: This will cause data loss on upgrades!

docs.title: 🔄 Auto-Updates
docs.text: Keep your emoji dataset fresh automatically! EmojiTools can check for and download the latest emoji data from Unicode CLDR without you lifting a finger.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Enable automatic updates (checks every 7 days)
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate

# Enable with scheduled task for background updates
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate -CreateScheduledTask

That's it! Your emoji dataset will stay current automatically.

docs.title: ✨ Why Auto-Updates?
docs.text:
• 📅 Stay Current - Get new emojis as Unicode releases them
  • 🔄 Set & Forget - Configure once, update forever
  • ⚡ Non-Intrusive - Silent background updates don't interrupt work
  • 🎯 Official Source - Updates from Unicode CLDR (the authoritative source)

docs.title: Automatic Checks
docs.text:
When enabled, EmojiTools checks your dataset age each time the module loads:

  1. Module loads → Checks last update date
  2. If outdated → Downloads latest from Unicode CLDR
  3. Updates silently → No interruption to your work
  4. You're current → Always have the latest emojis

docs.title: Dataset Sources
docs.text:
Unicode CLDR (Default & Recommended) - 🏆 Official source from Unicode Consortium - 1,900+ emojis with official names - Updated with each Unicode release - Highest quality and accuracy

GitHub (Alternative) - 🐙 Community-maintained gemoji project - ~1,800 emojis - GitHub-specific aliases included - Fast and reliable

docs.title: Enable Auto-Updates
docs.text:
# Default: check every 7 days
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate

# Custom interval: check every 14 days
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate -Interval 14

# With scheduled task (runs at 3 AM daily)
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate -Interval 7 -CreateScheduledTask

docs.title: Check Current Status
docs.text:
See your dataset information and update status:

Get-EmojiDatasetInfo

Output includes: - 📁 Dataset file path and size - 📊 Emoji count and category breakdown - 🏷️ Data source and version - ⏰ Last update timestamp - ⚙️ Auto-update configuration - 💡 Update recommendations

docs.title: ⏰ Scheduled Tasks (Windows)
docs.text: Scheduled tasks run updates in the background at specific times, perfect for keeping datasets current without manual intervention.

docs.title: Create Scheduled Task
docs.text:
# Creates a task that runs at 3:00 AM
Enable-EmojiAutoUpdate -CreateScheduledTask -Interval 7

Task Details: - Runs daily at 3:00 AM - Checks every N days (based on interval) - Runs even if on battery power - Requires network connection - Runs silently in background

docs.title: What is an Emoji Dataset?
docs.text:
EmojiTools uses a local database of emojis (called a "dataset") that includes:

  • ✅ Every emoji character (🚀, ❤️, 🎉, etc.)
  • ✅ Official Unicode names
  • ✅ Categories (Smileys, Animals, Travel, etc.)
  • ✅ Searchable keywords and tags
  • ✅ Aliases for quick access

docs.title: Where Do Emojis Come From?
docs.text: The emojis come from the Unicode CLDR (Common Locale Data Repository)—the official source for emoji data used by all major platforms!

docs.title: 📥 Download Your First Dataset
docs.text:
Before you can search emojis, you need to download the dataset:

Update-EmojiDataset -Source Unicode

What happens:

  1. ⬇️ Downloads latest Unicode CLDR emoji data
  2. 📦 Extracts 1,900+ emojis with full metadata
  3. 💾 Saves to your local EmojiTools data directory
  4. ✅ Ready to use instantly!

Only Need to Do This Once

The dataset is saved locally, so you don't need to download it every time. Enable auto-updates to keep it current automatically!

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Getting EmojiTools up and running is quick and easy! Choose the installation method that works best for you.

docs.title: 📦 Install from PowerShell Gallery (Recommended)
docs.text:
The fastest way to get started is installing directly from the PowerShell Gallery:

# Install for your user account (no admin required)
Install-Module -Name EmojiTools -Scope CurrentUser

# Or install system-wide (requires admin)
Install-Module -Name EmojiTools -Scope AllUsers

That's it!

You're done! Jump to Quick Start to begin using EmojiTools.

Having permission issues?

If you see permission errors, use -Scope CurrentUser instead of -Scope AllUsers. This installs the module for your account only and doesn't require administrator privileges.

docs.text: Want to contribute or use the latest development version? Install from the GitHub repository:

cd EmojiTools

# Or clone via SSH
git clone git@github.com:Tsabo/EmojiTools.git
cd EmojiTools

docs.title: 2. Import the Module
docs.text:
# Import from the source directory
Import-Module .\src\EmojiTools.psd1

Development Installation

This method is great for testing new features or contributing to the project. You'll always have the latest code!

docs.title: 🔖 Emoji Aliases
docs.text: Aliases are shortcuts that let you access your favorite emojis instantly without searching. Think of them as speed-dial for emojis!

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Create an alias
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "rocket" -Emoji "🚀"

# Use the alias
Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "rocket"
# Result: 🚀

# Copy to clipboard
Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "rocket" -Copy

docs.title: ✨ Why Use Aliases?
docs.text:
• ⚡ Lightning Fast - No searching required, instant access
  • 🧠 Memorable - Use names you'll remember
  • ⌨️ Keyboard Friendly - Perfect for scripting and automation
  • 🎯 Consistent - Same alias works everywhere, every time

docs.title: Create Your First Aliases
docs.text:
Set up shortcuts for emojis you use all the time:

# Status indicators
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "done" -Emoji "✅"

# Reactions
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "nice" -Emoji "👍"
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "fire" -Emoji "🔥"

docs.text:

# Get the emoji
Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "fire"
# Result: 🔥

$status = Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "done"

docs.text:
Parameter Type Required Description -Alias String No The alias name to retrieve -List Switch No Show all available aliases -Copy Switch No Copy emoji to clipboard after retrieving

Pipeline Input: Accepts alias names as strings

docs.text:
Parameter Type Required Description -Alias String Yes The alias name (letters, numbers, underscores only) -Emoji String Yes The emoji character to associate -Force Switch No Overwrite if alias already exists

docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description -Alias String Yes The alias name to update -Emoji String Yes The new emoji character

docs.text:

docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description -Force Switch No Overwrite existing aliases with defaults

docs.title: 💡 Pro Tips
docs.text:
Naming Convention

Use consistent naming for easier recall: 

# Good: descriptive and memorable
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "success" -Emoji "✅"
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "error" -Emoji "❌"

# Avoid: too short or cryptic
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "s" -Emoji "✅"  # Hard to remember

Export and Share

Share aliases with your team by copying the aliases.json file: 

# Export location
$aliasPath = Join-Path $PSScriptRoot "..\data\aliases.json"

# Copy to team share
Copy-Item $aliasPath "\\teamshare\emojis\aliases.json"

Combine with Collections

Create aliases for your most-used collections: 

# Get most used emoji from collection
$topEmoji = (Get-EmojiCollection -Name "Favorites").emojis[0]
New-EmojiAlias -Alias "fav1" -Emoji $topEmoji

Script Integration

Use aliases in automated scripts for consistent branding: 

# Build script with branded emojis
$start = Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "rocket"
$done = Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "check"
$fail = Get-EmojiAlias -Alias "x"

Write-Host "$start Starting build..."
# ... build process ...
Write-Host "$done Build completed!"

  • ✅ Share - Export collections to share with your team

docs.text:

docs.title: 📤 Export & Share
docs.text: Export your emoji collections, search results, or the entire dataset to various formats for documentation, web pages, sharing with teams, or archiving.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Export all emojis to JSON
Export-Emoji -Format JSON -OutputPath "emojis.json"

# Export search results to HTML
Search-Emoji "heart" | Export-Emoji -Format HTML -OutputPath "hearts.html"

# Export a collection to Markdown
Export-Emoji -Format Markdown -Collection "Favorites" -OutputPath "my-favorites.md"

docs.title: ✨ Supported Formats
docs.text:
• 📄 JSON - Structured data for applications and APIs
  • 🌐 HTML - Beautiful web pages with themes and styling
  • 📝 Markdown - Documentation-friendly format for GitHub, wikis
  • 📊 CSV - Spreadsheet-compatible for Excel, Google Sheets

docs.text:

# Get JSON string without creating a file

# Use in other commands

docs.title: Export-Emoji
docs.text:
Parameter Type Required Description -Format String Yes Export format: JSON, HTML, Markdown, CSV -OutputPath String No File path for export (defaults to current directory) -Collection String/Object No Export a specific collection by name or object -Category String No Filter by category before exporting -Query String No Search query to filter emojis -Limit Int No Maximum number of emojis to export -Title String No Custom title for HTML/Markdown (default: "Emoji Collection") -IncludeMetadata Switch No Add export date, count, and source info -StyleTheme String No HTML theme: Light, Dark, Colorful (default: Light) -PassThru Switch No Return content to pipeline instead of file

Export-Emoji -Format HTML -Collection "TeamEmojis" -StyleTheme Colorful -Title "Our Team Emoji Guide" -IncludeMetadata

Export your collections to JSON for backup: 

Get-EmojiCollection | ForEach-Object {
    Export-Emoji -Format JSON -Collection $_.Name -OutputPath "backup-$($_.Name).json"
}

docs.title: 🎨 Emoji Picker
docs.text: The interactive emoji picker is your visual gateway to browsing and selecting emojis. It's perfect when you want to explore categories, compare options, or just browse through the collection.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Open the emoji picker
Show-EmojiPicker

That's it! A browser window opens with an interactive emoji picker. Click any emoji to copy it to your clipboard automatically.

docs.title: ✨ Features at a Glance
docs.text:
• 🔍 Real-Time Search - Type to filter emojis instantly as you search
  • 📂 Category Browsing - Filter by categories like "Smileys", "Animals", "Food"
  • 🎨 Skin Tone Selection - Choose different skin tones for applicable emojis
  • 🌓 Theme Support - Light, dark, or auto-detect system theme
  • 📋 Auto-Clipboard - Selected emojis automatically copy to clipboard
  • ⚡ Standalone Mode - Keep the picker open while working in PowerShell

docs.title: Basic Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open the picker: Run Show-EmojiPicker
  2. Browse or search: Use categories or type to search
  3. Click an emoji: It copies to clipboard automatically
  4. Paste anywhere: Use Ctrl+V to paste your emoji

docs.title: The Picker Interface
docs.text:
The emoji picker provides a beautiful, intuitive interface for browsing emojis:

Light ThemeDark ThemeCategory BrowsingSearch & Filter

Clean and professional - perfect for daytime use with excellent readability.

Easy on the eyes - ideal for late-night coding sessions or low-light environments.

Browse by category - filter to Smileys, Animals, Food, Travel, and more with one click!

Lightning-fast search - type to instantly filter thousands of emojis to find exactly what you need.

docs.title: Searching in the Picker
docs.text:
The picker includes a built-in search box that filters as you type:

Show-EmojiPicker
# Then type "heart" in the search box to see all heart emojis
# Or type "animal" to filter to animals

docs.title: Browse by Category
docs.text:
Pre-filter to a specific category when you open the picker:

# Show only smileys and emotions
Show-EmojiPicker -Category "Smileys & Emotion"

# Show only animals
Show-EmojiPicker -Category "Animals & Nature"

# Show only food
Show-EmojiPicker -Category "Food & Drink"

Available Categories: - Smileys & Emotion - People & Body - Animals & Nature - Food & Drink - Travel & Places - Activities - Objects - Symbols - Flags

docs.title: Browse Your Collection
docs.text:
Show only emojis from a saved collection:

# Show your "Favorites" collection in the picker
Show-EmojiPicker -Collection "Favorites"

# Show your project-specific emojis
Show-EmojiPicker -Collection "MyProject"

Collections First

Create collections for your frequently used emojis, then use the picker to browse them visually!

docs.title: Return Emoji to PowerShell
docs.text:
Instead of just copying to clipboard, return the selected emoji to a variable:

# Capture the selected emoji
$emoji = Show-EmojiPicker -ReturnEmoji
Write-Host "You selected: $emoji"

# Use in a string
$message = "$(Show-EmojiPicker -ReturnEmoji) Task complete!"
Write-Host $message

docs.title: Auto-Detect (Default)
docs.text:
The picker automatically matches your system's light/dark mode preference:

Show-EmojiPicker -Theme Auto

Perfect for bright environments or when you prefer high contrast.

docs.text:

Great for night-time use or reducing eye strain.

docs.title: 🔌 Standalone Mode
docs.text:
Standalone mode opens the picker as a static HTML page without a PowerShell server. This is perfect when you want to keep the picker open while continuing to work.

Show-EmojiPicker -Standalone

Standalone Mode Features:

✅ Keeps picker open - Doesn't block your PowerShell session ✅ Still copies to clipboard - Click to copy works normally ✅ No server needed - Works offline with pre-loaded data ❌ Can't return to PowerShell - -ReturnEmoji won't work 📌 Manual close - You need to close the browser tab yourself

docs.title: When to Use Standalone
docs.text:
Use -Standalone when you:

  • Want an emoji reference open while coding
  • Need to select multiple emojis over time
  • Don't need to capture the selection in PowerShell
  • Are in a restricted network environment

docs.title: Custom Port
docs.text:
If port 8321 is already in use, specify a different port:

Show-EmojiPicker -Port 9000

docs.title: Combining Options
docs.text:
You can combine multiple parameters for precise control:

# Dark theme, specific category, return to variable
$emoji = Show-EmojiPicker -Category "Smileys & Emotion" -Theme Dark -ReturnEmoji

# Standalone mode with collection filter
Show-EmojiPicker -Collection "Work" -Standalone -Theme Light

docs.title: Show-EmojiPicker
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description -Category String No Pre-filter to a specific category -Collection String No Show only emojis from this collection -Theme String No Visual theme: Light, Dark, or Auto (default: Auto) -ReturnEmoji Switch No Return selected emoji to pipeline instead of clipboard only -Port Int No HTTP server port (default: 8321) -Standalone Switch No Open as standalone HTML without server

docs.title: 💡 Pro Tips
docs.text:
Keyboard Shortcuts

  • Tab: Navigate between search and emojis
  • Enter: Select highlighted emoji
  • Escape: Close the picker
  • Type to search: Start typing to filter instantly

Multiple Selections

Use standalone mode if you need to copy multiple emojis. Each click copies to clipboard, so you can paste them one at a time.

Collection Preview

Use the picker to preview your collections before exporting or sharing them!

docs.title: Searching for Emojis
docs.text: The heart of EmojiTools is its powerful search engine. Whether you know exactly what you want or you're just browsing, you'll find the perfect emoji in seconds! 🔍

docs.title: 🎯 Basic Search
docs.text:
The simplest way to find emojis:

Search-Emoji "rocket"

Results: 

Emoji  Name              Category         Keywords
-----  ----              --------         --------
🚀     rocket           Travel & Places  launch, rocket, space
🧑‍🚀   astronaut        People & Body    astronaut, rocket, space
👨‍🚀   man astronaut    People & Body    astronaut, man, rocket

It's Fuzzy!

Search uses fuzzy matching, so typos and partial matches still work: 

Search-Emoji "roket"   # Still finds 🚀!
Search-Emoji "rok"     # Yep, still works!

docs.title: 🔎 What Gets Searched?
docs.text:
When you search, EmojiTools looks through:

  1. Emoji Names - The official Unicode name
  2. Keywords - Tags associated with the emoji
  3. Descriptions - Alternative descriptions
  4. Categories - The emoji's category

docs.text:
# Quick emoji finder function
function Find-Emoji($keyword) {
    $result = Search-Emoji $keyword | Select-Object -First 1
    Copy-Emoji $result.emoji
    Write-Host "✓ Copied $($result.emoji) ($($result.description))"
}

Tip #3: Browse Categories First

Get-Emoji -Category "Symbols" | Select-Object -First 20

Get-Emoji | Where-Object description -like "*music*"
